user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_unmap:
```c
void metal_dma_unmap(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg,
		  int nents)
{
	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/*If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);

	if (!dev || !dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap || !sg)
		return;
	dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg, nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_dma_unmap:
struct metal_bus_ops {
	void		(*bus_close)(struct metal_bus *bus);
	int		(*dev_open)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				    const char *dev_name,
				    struct metal_device **device);
	void		(*dev_close)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				     struct metal_device *device);
	void		(*dev_irq_ack)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				       struct metal_device *device,
				       int irq);
	int		(*dev_dma_map)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				       struct metal_device *device,
				       uint32_t dir,
				       struct metal_sg *sg_in,
				       int nents_in,
				       struct metal_sg *sg_out);
	void		(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct metal_bus *bus,
					 struct metal_device *device,
					 uint32_t dir,
					 struct metal_sg *sg,
					 int nents);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
void metal_dma_unmap(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg,
		  int nents)

int		(*dev_dma_map)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				 struct metal_device *device,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_in,
				 int nents_in,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_out);

void		(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct metal_bus *bus,
				 struct metal_device *device,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg,
				 int nents);
explanation: Fragments not listed were excluded because they are not relevant to Rule 8.13 (pointer-to-const) or are already const/output/obviously modifiable: - The atomic_thread_fence calls and the null-check/return logic do not involve pointer type qualifications and so are not relevant. - The dev_open declaration already uses const for dev_name, so no issue there. - The dev_open parameter struct metal_device **device and dev_dma_map’s sg_out are output parameters (pointers meant to be written by the callee) and therefore cannot be made pointer-to-const. - Bus/device operations such as bus_close, dev_close, and dev_irq_ack likely require modification of the bus/device state (so their pointer parameters are intentionally non-const) and were not flagged. The listed fragments are the places where input pointers are accepted as non-const and thus should be investigated for possible const-qualification per MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
